NPR political editor Ken Rudin joins us every Wednesday to parse the presidential campaign and other political news week.
Former rivals Obama and Clinton swap their funders' phone numbers, and go to New Hampshire.
A top McCain aide says a terrorist attack would help his candidate.
One of the most conservative members of the House loses a primary election to a more conservative Republican.
New polls show Obama stretching his lead to double digits, and we focus this week on Senator Obama's decision to finance his campaign with private money, after he promised to use public funds.
Does it matter that he broke his word, and how will all that money change the campaign?
Our phone number is 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog that's at npr.org/blogofthenation.
As usual, Political Junkie Ken Rudin joins us here at the Newseum, and as usual, we begin with a trivia question.
Hi, Ken.
Hi, Neal.
Well, this week, of course, we're going to talk about Barack Obama opting out of the public finance system.
And that gives him a ton of money to run, and perhaps opens up the map.
You know, a lot of times we've been running - the campaigns have been focusing on 14 to 18 states.
Barack Obama now has the ability to run 50 state campaigns.
So, the question is, when was the last time a presidential candidate won more states than his opponent, but lost the election?

If you think you know the last presidential candidate to win more states but lose the election, Give us a call, 800-989-8255, or zap us an email, talk@npr.org, and we'll also accept answers from the audience here at the Newseum.
Hillary Clinton returned to the United States Senate yesterday, and talked to reporters about a trip she and Barack Obama will make later this week to the tiny town of Unity, New Hampshire.
(Soundbite of speech)

It is particularly significant because it is an area where Senator Obama and I each got exactly the same number of votes, so this is going to be a symbolic event that I hope will rally the Democratic Party behind our nominee.
And, Ken, there's got to be a staffer somewhere who gets a lot of points for finding a town named Unity, where both people got 107 votes.
I know, they did - they do, there was no city in New Hampshire called ""I hate her guts.
(Soundbite of laughter)

But no, obviously there's a lot of - there was a lot of rancor, and I think Hillary Clinton has done everything she could to make it clear that she's going to everything she can to help elect Barack Obama in November.

But interesting, yesterday there was a statement, a one-line statement, from an aide of Bill Clinton who said he's supporting Barack Obama but would know effusiveness that you heard from Hillary Clinton.
And perhaps of more interest is that they're going to be meeting, I guess, here in Washington on Thursday night, before they go up to New Hampshire, with funders of Hillary Clinton.
Right, exactly.
I mean, they're going to probably try and help each other out.
For all the amount of money that Hillary Clinton's people raised, she's going to introduce Barack Obama to them, her bundlers.
Hopefully that - you know, hope to raise - for him get some of that financial action.
And at the same time, Barack Obama apparently has agreed to help Hillary Clinton retire her debt.
It's over 22 million dollars, and Barack Obama's people said they'll do whatever they can to help that out as well.
And interesting, in the recent public opinion polls - well, all of the polls show Obama with a lead over McCain.
The lead was pretty steady for awhile, six, seven, eight points in, around that area.
Then, the last couple of polls show him with a double-digit lead.
It was a very normal sort of day.
The problem arose in the vote counting process after the polls has closed.
There were inordinate delays.
It appeared that some of the tabulation forms have been tampered with.
There were anomalies on the numbers.
But it was not generalized.
It affected votes as there as we can figure out primarily in about 20 percent of the constituencies across the country over 210 constituencies.
So the overall problem was that the process, of course, was not sufficiently transparent and accountable.
Were you, in fact, urging Kenyan officials to run a recount?
No.
What we were urging is that the electoral commission do the maximum possible to review and check the numbers.
And we said at this point that the rule of law needs to be respected.
So there are, of course, legal recourses to pursuing allegations of vote tampering.
So you would say this is a legitimate result?
Despite the irregularities, you're confident that Mwai Kibaki was, in fact, the winner?
Well, what we're saying is that the process was not satisfactory.
But ultimately, there is a body in Kenya to make this decision, and it is the electoral commission.
And they made their decision.
And so what we've said now in a democratic society, there are means of redress and they have to be pursued.
But let me just make one other point, if I could.

First and foremost, I think it needs to be looked at in a political context and what we are saying is that the Kenyans on both sides of this divide, President Kibaki and rival Odinga, need to talk to each other and they need to work out a political way forward for the country.
Ambassador Ranneberger, as you say that though, events seem to be overtaking you.
Can you describe the scene there in the capital of Nairobi?
How widespread is the rioting that's going on?
Well, actually, Nairobi's fairly quiet tonight.
Yesterday, there were riots in the couple of the large slums and one or two other parts of the city.
And there had been problems in other parts of the country.
A number of people have been killed.
It's hard to say how many people at this point.
What I have seen is a strong deployment of police to control the situation and things at least in Nairobi seem to be substantially calmer.

Now, today, in his swearing-in remarks, President Kibaki extended his hands, said he was reaching out to all Kenyans, to AfriComm, and today, rival Odinga made a very good statement, calling all Kenyans to reject violence and emphasized the need for peace and to emphasize the need to follow the rule of law.
So we're hopeful that those statements will help to further calm the situation in the day or two ahead.
The violence in Kenya has been breaking down along ethnic lines -President Kibaki from the Kikuyu tribe and rival Odinga is a Luo.
And there are reports of tribal gangs going from house to house, dragging out victims.
Are you hearing those reports as well?
Yeah, but, I mean, it's hard if you're not here to (unintelligible) situation.
There have been instances, certainly, of violence between these groups.
The imagination runs wild when you think of those things.
There have been people killed as they say, but this is not something again to mask tribal violence or slaughter along those lines.
And to be very frank about it, I believe this violence that has occurred has actually jilted Kenyans.
And it's jolted the leadership of both sides as well.
And in a sense, it sobered them up.
And I do think we're starting to see indications that they realized the need to come together for the good of the nation as a whole.
I think both sides underestimated the degree to which this could become as potentially violent as it's become.
Okay.
Michael Rannenberger, the U.S.
ambassador to Kenya, speaking with us from Nairobi.
Ambassador Rannenberger, thanks very much.
No, thank you.

Yes.
Yes.

But in Baltimore, it's more than that.
It's Frank Zappa Day.

The prolific and quirky composer and musician was born in Baltimore and with his son, Dweezil Zappa, coming to town to play some of the old favorites, Mayor Sheila Dixon decided to make an official proclamation.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG ""DANCIN' FOOL"")

Whereas, Frank Zappa's artistry invoked many musical genres including rock, jazz, electronic and symphonic music and his lasting impact has left an indelible mark on the arts and all those who attempt to follow in his footsteps.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG ""CONCENTRATION MOON"")
(Singing) American way how did it start?
Thousands of creeps killed in the park.
American way.
And whereas, Frank Zappa has received worldwide recognition for his talents, innovation and defense of the First Amendment of the Bill of Rights of the Constitution of the United States.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

And whereas, representing the Zappa family, Dweezil Zappa is here today to embody his father's music and legacy on stage for the first time in Baltimore, making this an appropriate day to honor Frank Zappa's memory and his many great accomplishments.
